justification: The article notes that several studies "used behavioral economic simulations (such as hypothetical purchase tasks) and demonstrated that … [they] prompted changes in drug demand," explicitly linking the construct of drug demand to the hypothetical purchase task measure.

It states that "conventional forced choice tasks … can measure the overall proportion of (hypothetical) substance-related versus substance-free choice, and they are both considered measures of substance demand or value," directly pairing the construct with the forced-choice measure.

In the same passage, the authors add that VBDM tasks, alongside conventional forced choice tasks, "are both considered measures of substance demand or value," identifying VBDM tasks as another instrument for that construct.

The paper explains that fitting sequential-sampling decision models in VBDM "enables the quantification of the subjective value of different stimuli," indicating that the modelling procedure itself is the measurement tool for subjective value.

Discussing elevated hyperbolic discounting in addiction, the authors reference foundational delay-discounting work (e.g., Ainslie, 1975; Madden & Bickel, 2010) and a meta-analysis of the construct, implying that the standard delay-discounting tasks used in those studies serve as the measure of hyperbolic discounting.
